text.p: Lehman Brothers cut its fourth quarter and 1997 earnings per share (EPS) estimate for Oshap Technologies but maintained its 1-buy recommendation for shares in the Israeli-based software group.

Oshap reported third-quarter EPS of $0.01, unchanged from a year earlier. Excluding a one-time gain of $0.02 a share, EPS were slightly below expectations, Lehman analyst Theodor Kundtz said in a report.
Oshap benefited from strong results at Tecnomatix Technologies, in which it owns 2.7 million shares. But the company suffered from a revenue shortfall at its small software subsidiary Manof.
Kundtz revised his fourth-quarter EPS estimate to $0.02 from an earlier estimate of $0.07 as well as his full-year 1996 estimate to $0.06 from $0.11 and his 1997 estimate to $0.16 from $0.26.
"Oshap is building Manof marketing infrastructure in the UK and U.S., the benefits of which should become apparent in 1997," the report said.
Lehman maintained its buy recommendation, noting the value of Oshap's holding in Tecnomatix and its cash position, net of debt, of about $5.00 per share.
"In addition, no value is being placed on (its subsidiaries) Manof/Decalog, which we believe have considerable promise in the long run," the report said.
